title: Gallery: Merlier magic on Stage 2 of the Giro d'Italia
content:
Joe Robinson
10 May 2021

Belgian sprinter Tim Merlier takes victory from a bunch sprint on Stage 2 into Novara

Stage 2 of this year's Giro d'Italia was best described as a slow burner. A 179km pan flat course from Stupinigi to Novara, a three-man breakaway with no threat to the Maglia Rosa, a lack of technical roads added up to a guaranteed sprint finish.

To be honest, it was the commentary teams tasked with providing extensive coverage of the entire stage that I felt sorry for. It was almost as if Patrick Lefevere gifted them the news Sam Bennett was leaving Deceuninck-QuickStep at the end of the season earlier that day so they had something actually interesting to talk about.

Not until the final 10km did the race show any sign of a pulse and even then, the most exciting moment was when a rider from the peloton chucked his bottle in a designated litter zone only for it to directly hit a telephone pole and then explode over a poor lady below. It really was that unremarkable.

The stage was eventually won in a sprint, comfortably, by Grand Tour debutant Tim Merlier of Alpecin-Fenix, a team also making their introduction to three-week racing. Proof if ever you needed it that they are much more than just Mathieu van der Poel.

Merlier beat Qhubeka-Assos's Giamcomo Nizzolo (who made it a record 11 second-place finishes at the Giro without victory) and Cofidis's Elia Viviani into third. Also, a thought for UAE Team Emirates sprinter Fernando Gaviria who was denied an opportunity at victory yesterday after being pushed into the barriers by his own teammate.

Thankfully both stayed upright and no one was hurt, but I wouldn't have wanted to sit between them at dinner that evening.
